name: Thirumalirunjolai
thirukkolam: Standing posture along with Sridevi, Bhoodevi, and the five weapons (Panchayudha) including the Prayoga Chakra.
theertham: Noopura Gangai, also known as Silambaru.
festivals: Chithirai Pournami Festivalâ€”the festival where the Lord departs for Madurai to witness the wedding of his sister, Meenakshi.
notes: There is a belief that every night at midnight, Lord Yama (God of Death) visits this shrine to worship Lord Alagar.

name: Srivilliputhur
thirukkolam: Vatapatra Sayanam (Reclining on a banyan leaf)
mangalasasanam: Both Periyazhwar and Sri Andal; 2 Pasurams (hymns)
festivals: Throughout the month of Margazhi, the thirty Thiruppavai hymns composed by Sri Andal are recited along with lullabies.
In the month of Aadi, the Pooram star (the birth star of Andal) is celebrated grandly.
The Brahmotsavam is held very grandly.
On the 5th day, the Five Perumals appear in the Garuda Seva, and on the 9th day, the Chariot Festival (Ther) takes place.
notes: The temple tower (Gopuram) is 164 feet high and is the official emblem of the Tamil Nadu government.
The idol of Lakshmi Narayanan, worshipped by Periyazhwar during his lifetime, is kept and worshipped in a separate shrine today.

name: Thirukkoodal
theertham: Chakra Theertham, Krithamala River, Vaigai River
festivals: Garuda Seva on the full moon day of the month of Aani.
Sayana festival and Mukkani (three fruits) festival.
Ennai Kappu festival.
The Periyazhwar festival takes place for ten days during the Swathi star in the month of Aani.
The Navaratri festival in the month of Purattasi is celebrated grandly.
notes: Among 96 types of Vimanams, the first and most magnificent is the Ashtanga Vimanam.
Koodalazhagar is the Lord who gives darsan (Sevai) across the four Yugas.
This is the place where Periyazhwar sang the "Thirupallandu" (sacred hymn).

name: Thiruvaramangai
thirukkolam: Coronation posture (Pattabhisheka Thirukkolam), sitting with two consorts.
vimanam: Sri Vaikunda Vimanam (also known as Nanda-varthana Vimanam)
witnesses: Brahma, Indra, Romasa Maharishi, Bhrigu Maharishi, Markandeya, Garuda, Urvashi, Tilottama, and the King of Sindhu.
festivals: Two Brahmotsavams are celebrated grandly in the months of Chithirai and Panguni.
On Thai Amavasya (New Moon in January/February), a special oil abhishekam (Ennai Kappu) is performed using one "kottai" (a large measure) of oil.
Once every 6 years, one lakh (100,000) lamps are lit in the temple.
notes: The oil used for the Ennai Kappu ceremony is collected in a well and sold to devotees, as it is considered a medicinal cure for diseases.

name: Thirukkurugur
witnesses: Brahma, Nammazhwar, Sangadu Thandan, Rishis, Madhurakavi Azhwar.
festivals: This is the birthplace of Nammazhwar.
He incarnated on the day of the Visaka star in the month of Vaikasi; the chariot festival and Theerthavari are held on that day.
On the fifth day of the Vaikasi festival, the "Nava Tirupathi" Garuda Seva occurs, where the deities of the 9 nearby Divya Desams arrive on Garuda mounts to visit Azhwar Thirunagari.
notes: There is a musical stone Nadaswaram (stone pipe) carved from rock at this site.
The statues of Nammazhwar, Ramanuja, and the Vigraham (deity) made by boiling water (Thamirabarani) are located here.

name: Srirangam
festivals: During the month of Margazhi, "Pagal Pathu" and "Ra Pathu" festivals are celebrated grandly.
On Vaikunda Ekadasi, when the "Ra Pathu" festival begins, the Lord provides darsan through the Paramapada Vaasal (gateway to heaven) adorned in the Ratna Angi (gem-studded armor).
It is believed that on the 10th day of the "Ra Pathu" festival, Nammazhwar attains Moksha.

name: Nachiyar Koil
thirukkolam: Standing posture, appearing as if marrying the Goddess.
festivals: The Kal Garuda (Stone Garuda) vehicle service occurs twice a year on the fourth day of the Brahmotsavam in the months of Margazhi and Panguni.
Garuda is adorned with eight snakes as ornaments.
notes: Only 4 people carry the vehicle from the sanctum. As it moves out, its weight increases, requiring 16 people, then 32 people at the next circuit, and finally 64 people to carry it.

name: Thirukkudanthai
thirukkolam: Reclining posture; the posture of slightly raising the body while supporting it with the hands. Known as Utthana Sayana posture.
festivals: Once every 12 years, when Jupiter enters the Aquarius (Kumba) zodiac sign, Kumbh Mela is celebrated.
Chithirai month chariot festival.
devotees: 1 million devotees visit. For the Chithirai month chariot festival, 100,000 devotees visit.
notes: In this temple, the main sanctum (Garbhagriha) of the Lord is designed in the shape of a chariot with four wheels, as if pulled by horses. It is constructed entirely of granite.

name: Thirukkacchi Athigiri
theertham: Sri Anantha Saras Theertham (Sri Athigiri Varadar resides within this sacred water)
mangalasasanam: Hymns sung by Boothathalvar, Peyalvar, and Thirumalisai Alvar; a total of 7 Pasurams (verses)
witnesses: Brahma, Bhrigu Muni, Gajendran, Brihaspati, Adiseshan, King Citra, and Saraswati
festivals: On the third day of the Brahmotsavam held in the Tamil month of Vaikasi, Sri Varadharaja Perumal appears on the Garuda Vahana (mount).
notes: There are 14 Divya Desams in the city of Kanchi.
Kanchi is a city where the sound of the Vedas is constantly heard throughout the Divya Desam.

name: Manimada Kovil
festivals: On the day after Thai Amavasya, the deities of the 11 Divya Desams assemble at a pandal in front of Manimada Kovil.
Thirumangai Alvar goes before each deity and performs Mangalasasanam by singing the verses he composed for them.
The 11 Divya Desam deities then process through the streets on Garuda Vahana.
notes: The 11 Divya Desams are situated within a 4 km radius.
